The confidence idea has been worked on.  I mentioned this paper before
in t=
his group... it describes evolving networks that output what is
essentially=
 a confidence level:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?bruce:gecco01

(Note =
I am not an author although it's from our research group)

ken

--- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> The recent talk=
 on bidding prompted an idea...
> 
> Has anyone ever trained or evolved a n=
etwork where one of the
outputs is 
> like a 'confidence' level in that it =
is an estimate of the error of
the rest 
> of the output?
> 
> In other wor=
ds, suppose you have 2 outputs.  Output A and B.  A is
the real 
> output. =
 There is an expected output for A.    There is an error
value for 
> A.  T=
he expected output of B is then the error value of A.
> 
> Why bother?  Wel=
l, suppose that you have evolved 100 solutions to a
problem. 
>   Some are =
better for one kind of input, others are better at
another.  You 
> could l=
et the networks themselves decide which one is best suited
for a 
> particu=
lar input, and you could use the correlation between
estimated error 
> and=
 output values to calculate a more precise output for the whole
network.
> =

> For example, network 1 has an output of 5 with an error value of
(e.g.) =
2.  
> That means, for the sake of illustration, that the real output will
=
be 
> somewhere between 3 and 7.  A second network has an output of 7
with =
an 
> error of 0.5.  So the real value is between 6.5 and 7.5.  If you
took=
 the 
> average of the output values, the result is 6.  But if you took the=

center 
> of the overlap, the output becomes 6.75.  That value might be mu=
ch
closer to 
> the correct value than just the average of the two networks=
.
> 
> Admittedly, it forces the network to calculate a more complex
functi=
on.  But 
> it might be useful, who knows?
>
